quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 11: Unit 5 Quiz 8
quiz.subtitle: 5.8: Calculations: Heat of Phase Changes
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Quantitative analysis of phase change energy

questions.question: Which formula should be used to calculate the energy required to melt a solid at its melting point?
questions.explanation: At the melting point, the temperature does not change ($\Delta T = 0$), so we use the mass or moles multiplied by the latent heat of fusion.

questions.question: The specific heat capacity of liquid water is $4.18$ J/g°C. How much heat is needed to raise the temperature of $50.0$ g of water from $20$°C to $80$°C?
questions.explanation: Using $q = mc\Delta T$: $50.0\text{ g} \cdot 4.18\text{ J/g°C} \cdot (80-20)\text{°C} = 50 \cdot 4.18 \cdot 60 = 12,540\text{ J}$.

questions.question: If the molar heat of fusion for water is $6.01$ kJ/mol, how much energy is required to melt $2.00$ moles of ice at $0$°C?
Why is the molar heat of vaporization ($\Delta H_{vap}$) for a substance almost always larger than its molar heat of fusion ($\Delta H_{fus}$)?
options: Vaporization requires completely overcoming intermolecular forces, while melting only partially disrupts them
Gas particles are larger than liquid particles
Melting occurs at a higher temperature than boiling
The specific heat of a gas is always higher than that of a solid
questions.explanation: In a liquid, molecules are still in contact. To turn a liquid into a gas, you must separate them entirely, which requires significantly more energy.

questions.question: How much heat is released when $10.0$ g of steam condenses to liquid water at $100$°C? ($\Delta H_{vap} = 2260$ J/g)
questions.explanation: Condensation is the reverse of vaporization. $q = m \cdot \Delta H_{vap} = 10.0\text{ g} \cdot 2260\text{ J/g} = 22,600\text{ J}$. The energy is released (exothermic).

questions.question: To calculate the total energy to turn ice at $-10$°C into steam at $110$°C, how many distinct calculation steps (sections of the heating curve) are required?
questions.explanation: The steps are: 1. Warm ice to $0$°C, 2. Melt ice, 3. Warm water to $100$°C, 4. Boil water, 5. Warm steam to $110$°C.

questions.question: A $100$ g piece of metal at $150$°C is dropped into $100$ g of water at $25$°C. If the specific heat of the metal is much lower than water, the final equilibrium temperature will be:
questions.explanation: Water has a very high specific heat capacity, meaning it takes a lot of energy to change its temperature. The metal will lose a lot of temperature while the water only gains a little.

questions.question: Which process is exothermic?
questions.explanation: Exothermic processes release heat to the surroundings. Gas turning into a solid (deposition) involves particles losing energy to settle into a lattice.

questions.question: What happens to the temperature of a sample of water while it is freezing?
options: It increases slightly due to the heat of fusion
questions.explanation: As long as liquid water is transitioning to ice, the temperature stays at the freezing point until all the liquid has solidified.

questions.question: In the equation $q = m \cdot c \cdot \Delta T$, what does 'c' represent?
questions.explanation: Specific heat capacity is the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of $1$ gram of a substance by $1$ degree Celsius.
